awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Development of an Innovative Ultra High Performance Concrete Foundation System with Bio-inspired Surfaces to Support Renewable Offshore Wind Turbines
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to develop a marketable and cost-effective U.S. manufactured foundation system to support offshore wind turbines (OWTs). The planned offshore wind energy production in the U.S. has been growing rapidly and the industry is expected to be worth more than $1 trillion within the next two decades. Although only 42 megawatts (MW) of offshore wind energy were installed in the U.S. during the last 10 years, planned projects have been growing rapidly targeting 30 gigawatts (GW) by 2030 and 110 GW by 2050, with strong support from coastal states. Achieving the targets of offshore wind energy requires cost-effective and innovative components of these energy systems. One of the main costs for offshore wind energy systems is their foundations, with costs typically ranging from 14% to 34% of the overall project cost. OWTs are commonly supported on large-diameter foundations, which the U.S. does not have the capability to fabricate and instead relies on foundations fabricated abroad. Therefore, a U.S.-manufactured foundation system to support renewable offshore wind energy infrastructure, enhance domestic supply chains, and reduce dependency on foreign manufactured foundations is proposed. The result of this research is a U.S.-manufactured alternative with savings of over half the cost per meter, enabling wider adoption of alternative energy harnessing technologies.


The goal of the proposed project is to develop a U.S.-manufactured, bio-inspired, enhanced capacity foundation system to support offshore wind energy infrastructure that provides technical improvements and cost-saving to currently used systems. The proposed project also provides: (1) ease of adoption by providing similar weight and installation approaches to current means and methods; (2) better durability and longer service life than currently used OWT foundations; and (3) improved speed of construction promoting scalability. Furthermore, the proposed system will allow for optimized design, increasing the foundation capacity and improving the installation process.  Preliminary tests show that the proposed design could improve the foundation capacity by up to 100% compared to that of the currently used foundation systems when subjected to long-term cyclic loading similar to those experienced by OWTs.  The proposed concept could be used as a driven pile, suction caisson, anchors, or gravity base providing several options for the offshore wind energy industry in the U.S. To achieve the project goal, this research will focus on: (1) verification of key material properties for marine environmental conditions, (2) structural design of foundation cross-sections, (3) installation analyses on proposed foundations in marine environments; and (4) investigations of the effects of the bio-inspired design on foundation capacity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The planned offshore wind energy (OWE) production in the U.S. has been growing rapidly and the industry is expected to be worth more than $1 Trillion within the next two decades. Although only limited OWE were installed in the US during the last 10 years, planned projects have been growing rapidly targeting 30 GW by 2030 and 110 GW by 2050 with strong support from coastal states. Achieving the targets of OWE requires cost-effective and innovative components of these energy systems. One of the main costs for OWE systems is their foundations. For example, the cost of foundations supporting offshore wind turbines (OWTs) typically ranges from 14% to 34% of the overall project cost; hence, up to 30% of recent investments in the OWE sector has been related to reducing foundations cost. Fixed-bottom and floating OWTs are supported on large-diameter steel foundations (piles, anchors or suction caissons). Currently the U.S. does not have the capability to fabricate large diameter steel foundations supporting OWTs and instead relies on foundations fabricated abroad. Increased foreign demand for steel and issues related to the COVID-19 pandemic has increased the costs over 200% of pre-pandemic levels. In addition, lead-time required for these systems can severely impact the construction schedule and U.S. plans.

 

Therefore, the research team proposed a U.S. manufactured Ultra High-Performance Concrete (UHPC) foundation system to support renewable OWE infrastructure. The goal of this first phase project was to develop a U.S. manufactured, UHPC foundation with bio-inspired surface elements to support renewable OWE infrastructure. The proposed concept can be used as driven piles, suction caisson, and anchors supporting fixed-bottom and floating OWTs. The UHPC foundation is a domestic product with scalability similar to commodity precast prestressed concrete products in the marketplace. The use of UHPC as the structural material allows for integration of complex bio-inspired surface topologies during casting. These surface characteristics improve the foundation axial capacity, which may result in reduced foundation length thus greatly improving the economics of the system and ease the deployment of OWE systems.

 

This first phase of the project focused on developing the basic principles and properties for the foundation alternative. Our efforts in this phase focused on material characteristics, structural capacity of designed UHPC foundations cross-sections compared to the current state of the practice, and the effects of surface elements on the soil-pile interaction when subjected to axial loading. The soil-pile interaction was investigated using plates with different designs of surface elements installed in clayey soil, small-scale piles and larger-scale piles subjected to axial loading that are installed in sandy soil. The results from both experimental tests and theoretical analyses reveal the following conclusions: (1) the excellent mechanical properties of Ultra High-Performance Concrete enabled an industry comparable cross section to be designed with both an 8-in. thick and 5-in. wall ribbed piling to meet the industry's average load demand for OWTs. Moreover, the buckling resistance of the 5-in. wall ribbed pile is approximately three times greater than that of the 8-in. thick pile; (2) under axial compression loads, without the presence of transverse reinforcement (spirals or ties), piles with thicker walls exhibit a higher applied load to theoretical capacity ratio.  A 3-in thick wall was capable of nearly the full axial load without transverse reinforcement; (3) In soil-pile interaction testing, plate tests in clayey soils, and small-diameter and larger-diameter pile tests in sandy soil, piles with surface elements that have center-center spacing (Sc) to height (h) ratio, named asperity ratio (Sc/h), between 7 and 36 were tested. The rough surface piles with an Sc/h ratio of 7 to 8 mobilized the largest soil-pile interface shear strength with up to 78% larger than the interface shear strength mobilized from the smooth surface. The research team anticipates to submit three manuscripts for publication after the end of the project. Three students participated in the work on this project, two of whom are female students. It is worth noting that during this first phase of this project, the behavior of UHPC pile subjected to lateral loading, combined axial and lateral loading, and moment were not tested. Furthermore, installation of UHPC foundation using driving or suction were not evaluated in the laboratory.  

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2023
Modified by: Jp Binard
